newsitem.title: POLAND: Poland seeks to clarify state guarantee system.
newsitem.headline: Poland seeks to clarify state guarantee system.

text.p: A bill now before Poland's parliament will clarify procedures for awarding government guarantees for loans on projects and adjust them to EU standards, a finance ministry official said on Thursday.
Piotr Dziewulski, director of the ministry's public debts department, said the bill allows the government to extend guarantees for up to 60 percent of the credit for a given project.

Under the bill, which needs to clear the senate and be signed by the president, guarantees amounting to more than 15 million Ecus would have to be approved by the full cabinet, Dziewulski told Reuters in an interview.
Guarantees of between 1.5 and 15 million Ecus would be extended by the finance ministry and those of below 1.5 million Ecus by the National Credit Guarantee Funds (KFPG).
The bill was approved by the lower house of parliament last week in a 377 to 17 vote with five abstentions.
Dziewulski said the bill would oblige the government to calculate the total amount of guarantees it had extended.
"Within six months after the bill takes effect, we should know how much the government has guaranteed," he said.
Dziewulski said the bill would make it easier to control the public debt.
